newsitem.title: RUSSIA: RUSSIAN LONG-TERM GOVT PAPER YIELD DOWN, ROUBLE UP.
newsitem.headline: RUSSIAN LONG-TERM GOVT PAPER YIELD DOWN, ROUBLE UP.

text.p: Russian government securities with maturities of between four to eight years made their trading debut on Friday, sparking demand for other long paper and pushing yields on long-term debt down, dealers said.
The rouble edged up on rouble purchases by the central bank and arbitrage.
*Banks transferred 1.68 trln rbls for trading
*Central bank sold 543 bln rbls of T-bills
*Average yield rose to 18.1 pct from 17.9 pct on Thursday
*Turnover fell to 3.27 trln rbls from 4.15 trln rbls
rouble/dollar Aug 1 July 31
midday afternoon close
tomorrow settlement 5,799-01 5,809-10 5,809-10
overnight credits (%) 10-14 6-8 7-12

The Russian Central Bank started offering 30.71 trillion roubles in five OFZ interest-bearing bond issues, each with an annual yield of 17.5 percent and maturities running from four to eight years, from its portfolio on Thursday.
Although the yield is lower than on long-term GKO discount Treasury bills, the market bought the new paper in anticipation of even lower-yield paper to come, dealers said.
"The offer of the paper gives a new orientation for yields on long-term instruments," one dealer said.

"Under these conditions, even if there is not very much money in the trading system, it is only natural for the market participants to start thinking about what the situation will be later, although it is admittedly economically unprofitable to buy the OFZs."
Annual government paper yields have fallen to about 18 percent annually from about 30 percent in May and the goverment said they would fall even further.
United City Bank dealer Stanislav Kuchinsky said the fact that there were deals, no matter how few, indicating players believed government prognoses that yields would fall further.

"The yields have already hit bottom, but they will not go up as we can see that huge sales by the Finance Ministry do not lead to a rise in the rates. The market absorbs them happily," Kuchinsky said.
"Prices of long-term T-bills went up because of this, but the Finance Ministry sales slowed it down."
The Finance Ministry sold 1.5 trillion roubles worth of long-term T-bills this week.
On the foreign exchange market, the rouble firmed, dealers said.

"The reason for the shortage is that a lot of roubles went to the central bank as banks have been buying hard currency from it in small lots," a Mezhkombank dealer said. "Banks probably also have rouble payments to make."
--Anna Smirnova, Moscow Newsroom, +7095 941 8520
